newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - Feb 24.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - Feb 24.

text.p: The New York Times reported the following business stories on Monday:

* Chubb Corp could soon announce the sale of its life insurance unit to Jefferson-Pilot Corp, and it is also in final negotiations with Patriot American and Beacon Properties for 80 percent of its real estate business holdings for about $1 billion, including debt.

* Animators such as Andrew Stanton, the writer of Walt Disney's and Pixar Animation Studios' "Toy Story," are reaping big profits from Hollywood's animation gold rush. Meanwhile, Pixar is close to a deal with Disney to sharply increase its share of profits in jointly-made movies.
* A new study indicates communications technology is becoming more equally distributed across the United States.
* Robert Scott, the Morgan Stanley executive overseeing the company's $10.2 billion merger with Dean Witter, suffered a heart attack last week while vacationing in the Caribbean.
* Raytheon says it may sell or merge its appliance business, which makes Amana stoves and Speed Queen washers and had 1996 revenues of about $1.5 billion.

* PPL Therapeutics, a small biotechnology company in Edinburgh, has the rights to the technology developed at the Roslin Institute, which worked with British embryologist Ian Wilmut to successfully clone an adult sheep.
* Health plans are testing "telemedicine", a less costly approach to traditional house calls that allows nurses and other health aides to check patients via cameras and microphones.

* Advertising Age's criticisms of a new ad created for Miller Lite beer by Fallon McElligott has caused a rift between the Minneapolis advertising agency and the advertising trade publication owned by Crane Communications.

* Advertising on the World Wide Web surged in 1996 to a range of $200 million from $55 million in 1995, but much of the rise came from technology companies, making it hard to calculate the potential of Web advertising.

* Cyber Freeway, Bigger.net and Smart World Communications are among the on-line service providers who have done away with monthly service fees and plan to earn their revenues almost exclusively from advertising.
* Richard Connor, who was fired as publisher of the Fort Worth Star-Telegram newspaper earlier this month, said he is trying to form a group to buy the paper from Disney.
* Swiss giant Novartis is preparing to support labeling of all genetically engineered crops and food products.
* Album sales of musicians who handed out awards for last year's Grammys rose an overall of 34 percent, while those for musicians who won Grammys rose only 26 percent.
* Unions face serious obstacles in the South, despite new attention on the region by the AFL-CIO.

* The editor in charge of Mississippi's only state-wide paper lost his job following the paper's coverage of a mysterious auto crash involving Governor Kirk Fordice and a memo issued before the crash urging more positive coverage of the "Republican revolution".
